Considering presented above immunohistochemical findings that CX3CL1 shown higher expression of CX3CL1 in the BLA under basal conditions, it might modulate neuronal activity and excitability in this area. 
To test this hypothesis, it was investigated whether CX3CL1 could directly affect the excitability of principal cells, the most numerous neurons in the BLA, using a whole-cell patch-clamp technique, in a current-clamp configuration.<!--Given that principal cells' excitability has been consistently reported to influence not only activity within the BLA complex, but also in the CeA, and within ITCs clusters (see Section \@ref(BLAstructure)), this study investigated whether CX3CL1 may regulate excitability of those cells. First, I was interested in determining whether CX3CL1 affect any membrane properties of principal neurons in the BLA. Considering their efferents , the regulation of firing in those neurons is thought to have critical impact not only on other pyramidal cells within the BLA complex, but also on ITCs clusters and the CeA complex.// As these neurons receive many inputs from broad array of structures *in vivo*, together with their // -->

To validate whether CX3CL1-induced reduction in the excitability is dependent on CX3CL1 receptor, CX3CR1, the two approaches were used. 
First, before recordings, a subset of slices was incubated with antibody against CX3CR1 (2ng/ml). <!--jakieć cytowanie które też tak robiło? + dawka?-->
It was found that after incubation with CX3CR1 antibody the CX3CL1-induced reduction in principal cells' excitability was not statistically significant, however there still was a subset of neurons which reacted with depolarized action potential threshold (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)<!--which parts?-->).
Notably, slices used in this study were 300 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m thin, and the penetration of antibody was limited and estimated as `r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m under our experimental conditions, as was revealed by analysis of post-recording immunostaining on a subset of slices.<!--albo see i odwołanie do rysunku albo cytowanie Fogarty MJ, Hammond LA, Kanjhan R, Bellingham MC, Noakes PG. A method for the three-dimensional reconstruction of Neurobiotin-filled neurons and the location of their synaptic inputs. Front Neural Circuits 7: 153, 2013. /// Although our neurochemical immunolabeling is limited by antibody penetration, and is therefore confined to subsampling of cell bodies and neuronal arbors that lie within 32um of the surface of the slice, we found an association between sIPSC frequency and neurochemical-->
To this end, another subset of experiments were perfomed using pharmacological approach with selected AZD8797 to inhibit CX3CR1.<!-- by antagonist.// For this reason, we selected AZD8797  to  inhibit  CX3CR1  for  investigating  its pharmacological  role  towards  inflammation  during hypertension.  // For this reason, this observation was additionally confirmed using pharmacological inhibition of CX3CR1 receptor, a selective antagonist (AZD8797).--><!-- NIE WIEM CZY TO PISAĆ...Moreover, since 10 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M AZD8797 was previously reported to efficiently prevented CX3CL1-induced outcomes, along with its elimination of the observed effect on PCs' excitability, I decided to use this concentration experiments presented in this dissertation.--><!--We decided to use, in all future experiments, 100 nM of CXCL16 since, at this concentration, neuronal cell death was efficiently prevented ...At all the tested concentrations, CXCL16 per se was not toxic (data not shown). --><!-- w tym artykule odwołują się na [] czyli badania gdzie antagonista jest nazwany 18a też są spoko!!!! @karlstrm_2013--><!-- The in vivo IC  50  was  estimated at 2  μ  M (range, 1.5  –  4  μ  M).@ridderstadwollberg_2014  -->
As shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), AZD8797 prevented the CX3CL1-induced decrease in principal cells' excitability, manifested as more depolarized action potential threshold, and thereby additionally confirmed CX3CR1 mediation in the observed effect (`r CX3CL1_azdfrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`).
<!-- dodatkowa analiza porównująca ANTIBODY AND AZD + CX3CL1 czy napisanie o różnicy w proporcji odpowiadających komórek? -->
Of note, AZD9787 did not affect this parameter when applied alone (\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd), baseline in DMSO = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, AZD8797(10`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_azda_BLA_stat_tres`)). 

Since it is well-known that the CX3CR1 receptor is mostly expressed on microglia, the possible involvement of this type of glial cells in mediating CX3CL1-induced reduction of PCs excitability was investigated.<!-- citations--><!--wcześniej : the protocol to pharmacologically inhibit microglial cells using minocycline on acute brain slices were adapted from other studies. // Since we found that CXCR6 is functionally expressed on microglia (see Fig. 2), we wanted to investigate the possible involvement of microglia in mediating CXCL16-induced neuroprotective effect. For this reason we pretreated hippocampal neuronal cultures with minocycline, a tetracycline-like antibiotic known to inhibit microglia activation, before Glu insult.
-->
For this reason, the slices were pretreated with 100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M minocycline, a tetracycline-like antibiotic known to inhibit microglia activation, before and during CX3CL1 application.
As presented in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), the inhibition of microglial activity also diminished the CX3CL1-induced effect on the action potential threshold (`r CX3CL1_minofrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`).
In contrast, the minocycline applied alone increased the excitability of PCs (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, minocycline (100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_minoa_BLA_stat_tres`, \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd)). 
Thus, this finding highlights the potential importance of microglial functions in regulating the activity of neurons in the BLA. 

Finally, since the activity of principal cells in the BLA is well-known to be tightly controlled by heterogeneous group of interneurons, it was investigated whether blocking GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors would eliminate the effect of CX3CL1.<!-- To isolate AMPA-mediated eEPSCs, picrotoxin (100m) and APV (50m) were added to the bath /// ZMIENIĆ!!!!!!!!! I DODAĆ JACY ANTAGONIŚCI!!!!!!!!! dawki Treatment with both GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ antagonists (picrotoxin, 100 ... and ) ... fully abolished the neuronal response to CX3CL1.--> 
As expected, the CX3CL1 effect was fully abolished when the GABAergic receptors were blocked (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, CX3CL1 (2nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_gabafrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)).
Thus, these data suggest that CX3CL1 reduces principal cells' activity *via* CX3CR1-, microglia-, and interneuron-dependent manner.

Having established a significant suppression of principal cells' firing, which are the main group of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, following CX3CL1 treatment, the effects of this protein on the glutamatergic transmission in this area in *in vitro* slices was measured.
Spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents (sEPSCs) were recorded *via* whole-cell patch clamp recordings (held at −70 mV). 
<!--The representative traces of sEPSCs in the absence (referred to as control hereafter) or presence of harmine (10μM) (referred to as harmine) were shown in supplemental Fig. S1(A). -->
All measured parameters of excitatory synaptic transmission before and after application of CX3CL1, AZD8797, and minocycline are shown in details in Figs. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSCfigall1) \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSCfigall2) and summarized in Table 7.2<!--!--> in the Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sEPSCappendix).
Compared to the control, CX3CL1 in two doses (2nM and 5nM) had negligible effect on the median value of amplitude, frequency, and kinetics of sEPSC.
However, although statistically not significant, a proportion of neurons (`r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50%) reacted with decreased frequency of excitatory synaptic currents.<!-- CX3CL1 was shown to have negligible effect on the frequency of excitatory synaptic currents./// In contrast to inhibitory synaptic transmission, compared to baseline, CX3CL1 had negligible effect on the mean value of sEPSC amplitude and frequency, which was further described in the Appendix (see: \@ref(CX3CL1sEPSCappendix)). // found that although a partial reduction between NMDA and NMDA/CX3CL1 treated cells was observed, it was not statistical significant
-->
<!-- figures with decreased sEPSC + minocycline ...evoked and paired pulses? -->

Nevertheless, similar to previous findings, in addition to increased excitability, minocycline alone also altered sEPSC kinetics by increasing both their rise time and decay time \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSC).
Thus, these observations indicate that microglia may be a key contributors in the regulation of excitatory drive in the BLA.<!--jakoś inaczej napisać... microglia...? postsynaptic mechanisms?--><!-- Our findings overall highlight microglia and its receptor CX3CR1 as key contributors in regulation of social behavioral adaptation to chronic stress.-->

As local interneurons are considered to tightly regulate principal cells' activity<!--citation?--> together with results regarding principal cells' reduction in excitability indicated, among others, that CX3CL1 effect is mediated by GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors, the possible influence of CX3CL1 on the inhibitory transmission onto BLA PCs was next explored in *in vitro* slices.<!-- Next, We next explored the possible influence of harmine on the GABAergic transmission onto BA PNs. -->
Cells were clamped at 0 mV to record the spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents (sIPSCs).<!-- Spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents (sIPSCs) were recorded *via* whole-cell patch clamp recordings (held at −70 mV).  -->
The representative traces of sIPSCs in the absence (baseline) or presence of CX3CL1 (2 and 5nM) are shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC).
The dose 2nM did not affect any of the measured parameters measured of sIPSCs in this study (see Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix)), whereas at higher concentration (5nM) of CX3CL1 robustly<!--markedly--> reduced the median frequency and amplitude of GABAergic transmission onto principal cells in the BLA (from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` Hz and from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Amplitude)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Amplitude), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Amplitude)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Amplitude), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)`, respectively), compared to the control.
Further analysis of IPSCs kinetics showed that the median rise times and decay times<!--and mIPSCs--> remained unchanged (from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms and from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms, respectively), as reported by data in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSCappendixfig) in Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix).<!-- Data reported in Figure 1A confirms that--> 

Similarly to what was observed in PCs' excitability, AZD8797 and minocycline eliminates these CX3CL1-induced effects (`(round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)/round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r (round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)) / (round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3))` 
and `(round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)/round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)/ round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` % of sIPSC frequency during baseline condition, respectively), indicating a functional involvement of CX3CR1 and microglia in the modulation of BLA GABAergic transmission (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC)).<!-- suggesting a functional involvement of CCR2 in the modulation of spinal GABAergic transmission. lepsze słowo? // These effects were blocked in the presence of minocycline and minocycline, suggesting its dependency of CX3CR1- and microglia. -->

In parallel with this, the cumulative probability curve of sIPSC amplitude was considerably right-shifted (p = 0.0028, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test,supplemental, Fig. S2D). 
The cumulative probability curve of interevent interval, on the other hand, was left-shifted upon harmine treatment (p < 0.0001, Kolmogorov– Smirnov test, supplemental, Fig.S2E).  zmienić -->


In addition, to determine if the decrease in sIPSC frequency by CX3CL1 was due to a change in the spontaneous action potential firing in the slice, the TTX (500nM) was used to block neuronal firing.
The mIPSC amplitude, frequency, and kinetics was measured before and after CX3CL1 application (also clamped at 0 mV).<!-- Alternatively: To determine whether there was a direct effect of CX3CL1 on GABAergic terminals, miniature mIPSC (mIPSCs) were recorded from principal cells. In these experiments TTX was used to block the action potentials. -->
No changes were found after CX3CL1 treatment on those parameters (see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC), mIPSC frequency: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_freq`, mIPSC amplitude: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_amp`).
<!-- The mIPSC frequency data may be consistent with the paired-pulse data and suggests that D3Rs reduce GABA release at the local synapses. However, the mIPSC amplitude data, along with the absence of any effect on PPRs at the LPC synapses, suggests that D3Rs may also modulate local and LPC synapses via a postsynaptic mechanism as well. -->
Hence, data presented here suggest that CX3CL1 reduces GABA release at the local BLA synapses, probably by depression of the spontaneous firing of local interneurons.<!-- przemyśleć to jeszcze-->
Notably, the decreased sIPSC amplitude<!-- , along with the absence of any effect on PPRs at the LPC synapses,--> suggests that this signaling molecule might also modulate synapses *via* a postsynaptic mechanism. 
Moreover, this inhibition of GABAergic transmission by 5nM CX3CL1 was mediated by both CX3CR1 and microglia.

#### CX3CL1 impairs the long-term potentiation in the BLA


Considering studies indicating CX3CL1 involvement in memory, along with presented here depression of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, the next step was to gain insights into how CX3CL1 modulate the BLA network activity.
To this end, the extracellular recordings were employed and the amplitude of field potentials, short-term plasticity, and long-term potentiation were assessed.<!-- paired pulse ratio // LTP, which is closely related to memory formation and is predominately regulated by the glutamatergic system,  -->
At the beginning of each experiment the I/O curves were determined as shown in Figure \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)a. 
They were not significantly different between measured conditions, indicating that under our experimental conditions CX3CL1 did not modulate the baseline excitatory activity in the BLA.<!-- może jeszcze lepiej to napisać?-->
The paired-pulse ratio, which is a form of short-term plasticity sensitive to presynaptic changes [@stuart_1991], was also investigated.
<!-- jedno zdanie że external capsule input stimulation led to PPF in all experiments -->
Similarly, this parameter also remained unaffected by CX3CL1 treatment (see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)b), suggesting that CX3CL1 action in the BLA is rather not presynaptic.<!-- może też trochę lepiej napisać?--><!-- wcześniej: Comparing control and CX3CL1-applied slices, no significant effect on the basal excitability, as assessed by input – output curves, was found as well as the paired-pulse ratio remained unaffected by this manipulation (see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP), parts a and b). -->
<!-- jakieś ogólne zdanie o LTP? Two tetanic stimuli applied at 100 Hz to fibers running through the external capsule produced robust LA-LTP both in TPH2+/+and TPH2− / −mice. // TBS applied to the Schaffer collateral-CA1 pathway was also effective at inducing LTP both in TPH2+/+and TPH2− / −mice.-->
Notably, upon application of TBS<!--Theta Burst Stimulation-->, external capsule-evoked field potentials in the BLA were effectively potentiated in the control slices, but not in the slices treated with CX3CL1, as revealed by a significant decrease measured by the comparison of average potentiation before and after LTP induction (see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP), part c).<!-- moja statystyka do zrobienia... albo Bartkowa...(Figure 4g, t (16) = 4.03, P = 0.001)--><!-- poprawić mixed model repeated-measure ANOVA (group effect: (F (1,16) = 16.27, P = 0.001; and group × post-HFS time point interaction: F(2.071,33.136) = 9.231, P = 0.001, Greenhouse – Geisser correction; Figure 4f)// The comparison of average potentiation across time points after induction also revealed a highly significant difference between these two groups of slices (Figure 4g, t (16) = 4.03, P = 0.001).// Upon application of HFS, vSub-evoked field potentials in the BLA were effectively potentiated in the control group, but not in the NF knockdown group as revealed by mixed model  repeated-measure  ANOVA  (group  effect:  (F (1,16) = 16.27, P = 0.001; and group × post-HFS time point interaction: F(2.071,33.136) = 9.231, P = 0.001, Greenhouse – Geisser correction; Figure 4f). The comparison of average potentiation across time points after induction-->
Together, these findings demonstrate an <!--specific--> impairment of BLA synaptic plasticity to external capsule inputs after CX3CL1 treatment.<!-- of external capsule inputs to LA/BLA.-->
Considering that one of the mechanisms of synaptic plasticity are changes in dendritic spines morphology <!--inaczej to napisać-->, our next goal was to examine whether CX3CL1 affects dendrites morphology in the amygdala.

<!--The observed in this study reduced PCs' excitability, together with a decrease in GABAergic drive, was ...
As many reports indicated the effect of CX3CL1 on the LTP citations , together with accumulating evidence concerning the relevance of interneurons in this process in the BLA  citations , ...  dokończyć--><!--We assessed long-term potentiation (LTP) in the ventral external capsule– BLA pathway, which represents the major connection between cortex and BLA. -->
